awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Laser Spectroscopic Investigation of Vibronic Interactions in Free Radicals and Molecular Complexes
awd_abstract_narration:
With this CAREER award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Jinjun Liu of the University of Louisville to conduct experimental studies aimed at understanding how the vibration and electron motion are coupled in small reactive molecules and in ionic dimers. This coupling of electronic and vibrational degrees of freedom is ubiquitous in photochemical reactions, which are an important class of reactions in atmospheric chemistry and in other venues. Post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate students working on this project will receive  training in laser science, spectroscopy, and the design of experimental apparatus, while working on compelling chemical problems with significant real-world impact. Part of this CAREER program is also focused on a number of education projects, including the revamping of the physical chemistry curriculum and the involvement of underrepresented students in his research program.

Professor Jinjun Liu and his research group will use a suite of spectroscopic techniques to study the vibronic interactions in chemical species of significance to atmospheric chemistry, combustion chemistry, and other areas. Species to be studied include alkoxy radicals which will be created in an electric discharge and ion pairs of ionic liquids will be created with a heated nozzle. The methods used to interrogate these molecules include: (1) laser induced fluorescence (LIF); (2) dispersed fluorescence (DF); (3) and cavity ringdown spectroscopy (CRDS). More specifically, the alkoxy radical intermediates will be generated by either pulsed electric discharge or laser photolysis, while ion pairs of ionic liquids, a spectroscopically underexplored family of molecular complexes, will be studied in the gas phase using a heated nozzle. LIF and Ultraviolet-CRDS experiments will be conducted to explore the vibrational energy levels of high-lying electronic states, whereas DF- and mid-Infrared-CRDS techniques will be used to investigate the vibronic structure of the lowest electronic states. Spectroscopic study of isolated ionic liquids is aimed at understanding the Coulombic interaction and hydrogen bonding between ion pairs, determining the conformations of the molecular complexes, and connecting their microscopic structure to physiochemical properties.  In particular, it is anticipated that the work on Jahn-Teller and pseudo Jahn-Teller interactions will be of considerable  interest to theorists.

por.por_cntn:
The most precise and fundamental knowledge of molecules comes from high-resolution spectroscopy. Molecular spectroscopy provides quantitative insight into the structure and dynamics of molecules by studying their interaction with the electromagnetic wave. It has broad applications in both pure and applied sciences and industry. High-resolution spectra of molecules can be used as molecular “fingerprints” in combustion diagnostics, atmospheric chemistry, and astrochemistry. Therefore, molecular spectroscopy enables some indispensable methods for investigating chemical reaction kinetics. Furthermore, the complex interplay between the vibration and rotation of nuclei and motions of the electron, including its spin, can be unraveled through analyzing experimentally obtained spectra.  In atomic, molecular, and optical (AMO) physics, high-precision laser spectroscopy measurements have been used to test fundamental physical laws and search for new physics beyond the Standard Model.

Supported by the NSF, our lab has carried out spectroscopic studies of gas-phase molecules using state-of-the-art high-resolution laser systems and cutting-edge spectroscopy techniques. Our spectroscopy studies center on the detection and characterization of reactive chemical intermediates, e.g., free radicals and molecules in excited electronic states. The spectroscopic methods employed in our experiments include laser-induced fluorescence/dispersed fluorescence (LIF/DF) spectroscopy for alkoxy (RO⸱) radicals and cavity ring-down (CRD) spectroscopy for peroxy (ROO⸱) radicals. These two spectroscopic techniques (LIF/DF and CRDS) are also used to study metal-containing molecules as candidates for direct laser cooling and the search for the origin of the matter-antimatter imbalance in the Universe.

We are particularly interested in vibronic (vibrational-electronic) interactions that cause spontaneous distortion of the symmetry of polyatomic molecules and lower their energy. High-level quantum chemistry calculations are used to help understand the geometry, energy level structure, and dynamics of molecules on multiple potential energy surfaces (PESs).  Our group also developed spectroscopic models and software to analyze, simulate, and fit the vibronic, rotational and fine structure in experimentally obtained spectra.

The target molecules of our research, RO⸱ and ROO⸱ radicals, play important roles in combustion and atmospheric chemistry. Therefore, spectroscopic results from our research make contributions to the industry, environmental sciences, and policy-making. Experimentally obtained spectra with resolved vibronic or even rotational structures can be used as diagnostic tools in studies of chemical kinetics. In fundamental sciences, spectroscopic investigations of these molecules also aid in the study of spectroscopy and dynamics of molecules on multiple PESs. Intramolecular interactions in these molecules are long-standing subjects of computational chemistry and theoretical spectroscopy. The information about these molecules in the form of molecular constants derived in simulating and fitting experimental spectra provides critical benchmarks for quantum chemical calculations.

High-resolution spectroscopy is a highly interdisciplinary research field. In our lab, students gain hands-on experience in research lasers, optics, electronics, optical detection, data acquisition, vacuum systems, machinery, and computer hardware/software. They have the opportunity to develop and use in-house computer programs written in various computer languages. Students also learn the principles and applications of quantum mechanics, computational chemistry, thermodynamics, statistical physics, and modern molecular spectroscopy. With the knowledge and skills students master through rigorous training in our research lab, they will have a bright and broad career prospect after graduation, regardless of whether they stay in academia or enter the industrial world.

The PI is active in integrating research experiences into undergraduate teaching. As the instructor for a physical chemistry laboratories course, he designed new experiments for the course, including quantum chemical calculations and spectroscopic analysis. Many undergraduate students, most of which from the laboratory course, had their first research experiences in the PI’s research group. The PI also developed an advanced molecular spectroscopy course for graduate students. The course covers high-resolution molecular spectroscopy theories and their applications to real-world problems.
